formatted_address: Leonard Wood Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Bamboo Art Exhibit

review.text: If you want to experience the feeling of entering a haunted house forget about it. This is now CLOSED.

history: Baguio City's famed White House was the ancestral home of the Laperal Family. Some time after it was abandoned, word spread that it was haunted, and that strange noises emanate from its premises at night and that spirits could be seen moving around. Late last year (2013), it was converted and transformed into what is now reportedly the country's first and only BAMBOO MUSEUM, housing incredible works of art done on bamboo poles by skilled Ifugao craftsmen. It is indeed almost inconceivable how these extremely talented wood carvers (led by low-key ROLDAN PAIT of the Asin Bamboo Carvers Guild) were able to do such intricate and detailed works on singular bamboo poles. You really have to see it to believe it. With an entrance fee of just fifty pesos, there simply is no reason for you not to go there. Picture-taking is allowed. And visitors are even permitted to explore the upper floors of this erstwhile haunted house. Who knows, there might be some spirits still lurking there. Surely, you don’t want to miss Baguio's newest attraction!

formatted_address: Igorot Park, Camp John Hay, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Chocolate de Batirol

review.text: I didn't have enough photos as I was enjoying my hot chocolate and food. Their hot choco tastes different than the Swiss Miss you drink. It doesn't have milk or sugar. Just pure cocoa but its actually really good. I highly recommend visiting this place.

history: Established in 1996, Choco-Late' de Batirol is one of the most recognized restaurants in the Summer Capital of the Philippines. They're known for their namesake, a classic Filipino drink called the choco-late de batirol. It's made from fresh cacao, the main ingredient in making chocolate.

formatted_address: Baguio - La Trinidad - Bontoc Rd, Baguio, 2601 Benguet, Philippines
name: Valley of Colors

review.text: It is a nice spot for a photo. Good thing that you cant capture the smell. If you plan to go here, might as well go to strawberry farm after. Since, you already braved the traffic on seeing this place. Several more and you'll be at the strawberry farm.

history: The Valley of Colors is composed of three villages transformed from drab sights to a tourist attraction. These include the Stone Hill, Sadjap, and Batiwtiw. Since the project started in January of last year, over 180 houses were painted in bright colors and thus created a giant mural.

formatted_address: Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Cemetery Of Negativism

review.text: What makes me want to come back here over and over again is the concept of this place. I do, ironically, find solemn here and it's very calming walking around reading the head stones and making you realize things. The aesthetic kinda sucks but then again, the concept and uniqueness of this place turned me all around(ano daw?! Lol)

history: It's the Cemetery of Negativism also called the Lost Cemetery found near the historical core of Camp John Hay, Baguio. Written on the entrance of the Cemetery of Negativism: “Negativism is man's greatest self imposed infliction, his most limiting factor, his heaviest burden.

formatted_address: Dot-PTA Complex, Gov. Pack Rd, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Baguio Museum

review.text:
This place has a lot of interesting historical knowledge regarding Baguio City. The ones that caught my interest are the mummy and the scale maps of Baguio.

Sad thing though that the place is not well lit. Some floors are undergoing reconstruction as well. Some items are not displayed properly too.  

Entrance is 40 per person. Students have discount I think or are free.

history: Baguio Museum stands for, upholds, and embodies the cultural and historical heritage of Baguio City. Inspired by Ifugao architecture, the museum is made of stone and wood featuring a striking pyramid roof and two huge concrete poles at the stair entrance that resembles a traditional Ifugao home with an elevated floor supported by posts. This time-honored museum was built in 1975 at the corner of Governor Pack Road and Harrison Road. It was hit by a major earthquake in 1990 but was rebuilt after a decade to continue its purpose.

formatted_address: Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Sky Ranch Baguio

review.text: A good place to hang out with your loved ones especially with the kids if you're visiting Baguio. It's new so the amenities are good.

history: Sky Ranch opened with 12 rides including the Super Viking, Drop Tower, Carousel, Sky Cruiser, and Baguio Eye. ... The towering Baguio Eye which rises about 50 meters tall and 45 meters in diameter really catches everyone's attention especially during the night as it rotates with running colorfulights.

formatted_address: Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Green Valley Country Club

review.text: It's a good place to stay and good food also at the restaurant

history: Green Valley (Baguio) Hotel and Resort, Inc. was originally established and organized in December 1975 as The Green Valley Country Club, a club exclusively for its members and their dependents and guests. It remained as a country club until 1990 when an earthquake destroyed practically all hotels in Baguio City

formatted_address: Magsaysay Ave, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Baguio City Public Market

review.text: This market is pretty darn cool. We got some amazing stuff for really low prices and I love the food the vendors are selling. Lots of fun to hang out here.

history: The Baguio City Market is one of the most interesting public markets in the Philippines. It is crowded and lively, and offers many fascinating locally-made items from Baguio and the provinces of Benguet, La Union, Pangasinan, etc.

formatted_address: Harrison Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Baguio Night Market

review.text: One of the best places to eat fried cat fish or squid. Fresh food and lovely environment with a lot of people. Quite enjoyable

history: There are myriad of items to buy in Baguio Night Market, and it never fails to attract customers and travelers. Products offered here ranges from bags, footwear, clothing, and digital accessories. There are also souvenir items that you can buy in this place, even kitchenware too.

formatted_address: Country Club Rd, Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Baguio Country Club Christmas Village

review.text: I would have rated it higher. Maybe this will help in improving the famous Christmas village. I hope they improve their snow machine and not use soap suds, it is a bit disappointing and mediocre. It is also a bit crowded since the space is small and cramped. But overall, it is a nice place to visit during the holiday season.

history: As in the past, the highly acclaimed Christmas Village located across the country club’s main gate will showcase recycled materials – used materials from the club's daily operations – that have been turned into beautiful Christmas decorations.

formatted_address: Baguio, 2602 Benguet, Philippines
name: Rizal Park

review.text: Its amazing how a small city/town can provide a dedication for our country's national hero. Unfortunately the locals and tourist just dishonor him by making this beautiful place into a big trash bin. Instead of flowers and plants you will see piles of garbage from sticks, placti cups, unfinished foods etc. I hope there would be more trash bins and people who would maintain such magnificent park. Also the exsisting plants needs alot of tender loving care.

history: The execution of Filipino patriot José Rizal on December 30, 1896 fanned the flames of the 1896 Philippine Revolution against the Kingdom of Spain. The area was officially renamed Rizal Park in his honor, and the monument enshrining his remains serves as the park's symbolic focal point.

formatted_address: Mount Kabuyao, Tuba, Benguet, Philippines
name: Mount Kabuyao

review.text: Amazing veiw! :)

history: Mount Cabuyao (alternatively spelled as Mount Kabuyao) is a mountain in the Philippines located in the municipality of Tuba in the province of Benguet. Its summit, rising to more than 2,000 metres (6,600 ft) above sea level, overlooks the city of Baguio.

formatted_address: beside Rizal Elementary School Gibraltar Road Baguio Benguet PH, Gibraltar Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Wright Park

review.text:
Wright Park
Wright Park is a beautiful small park located in lush green scenic area of Baguio, Philippines. It is named after American Governor Luke Wright. It is adorned with a long reflecting pool lined with pine tree which gives mesmerizing beauty to the Park. An additional charm to the Park is the facility of pony ride and horse racing competition. Right in front of the Park is the Summer House of the President of Philippines called “The Mansion”.

history: Wright Park is named after its architect Governor Luke E. Wright who ordered architect Daniel Burnham to build the place with recreational facility for American soldiers and civilians.

formatted_address: 367 Long Long Benguet Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Tam-awan Village

review.text: Awesome historical place. Must visit. Do take the guided tour. Closes like 6 pm in the evening. So plan better.

history: Tam-awan Village in Pinsao Proper, Baguio City uniquely blends indigenous aesthetics and exquisite Cordilleran craftsmanship with an artist’s concept for a village adapting to Baguio setting.

formatted_address: Kennon Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Lions Head

review.text: Well the place is very beautiful, I fact the journey down the hill from top of the mountain until this point is beautiful. Due to landslide ahead we could not go beyond this point. Very clean and very good people around, try to click pictures in Baguio traditional dress just next to the lions head

history: The Lions Head is a statue along Kennon Road, a major highway in Luzon, Philippines that leads to the city of Baguio. Located in Camp 6, the Lion's Head measures 40 ft in height.

formatted_address: Burnham Lake, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Burnham Lake

review.text:
We had fun here in a pedalboat on November 22, 2018. 

Here is an excerpt from The Adventures of Kokoy - A Travel Guide:

"...At Burnham Lake in the middle of the park, you can rent a row boat, or, if you have three or fewer people in your party, a pedal boat, which is a good exercise people should be encouraged to do anyway. Don't expect much from boating on Burnham Lake; it is anti-climactic at best. It's not much of a lake at all. "Pool" would be a more apt title for it. There is nowhere to go except in circles, and the only sights to see beyond the flowerbeds and trees surrounding the pool are the tops of buildings, including city hall, numerous hotels, and SM City shopping mall. The true fun is in the laughter and fellowship you have with friends and family in the boat, and that is what Burnham Lake is truly all about..."

history: Burnham Park is named after Daniel Burnham, an American architect who was the city planner for Baguio. He designed the park and the original plans for the city simultaneously, and construction began around 1904. Burnham Park covers the only large expanse of level ground within hilly surroundings.

formatted_address: Mines View Observation Deck, Mines View, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Mines View Observation Deck

review.text: It was a long time since I last visited Baguio City. It was like 7 or 8 years ago. Coming back here with my girlfriend is such a memorable experience. The view and cool climate is awesome.

history: In the park is an Observation Deck that will enable the tourists to take an astonishing panoramic view that overlooks the mining town of Itogon which hosts the used to be a gold and copper mines of Benguet Corporation. A glimpse of the Amburayan Valley can also be witnessed at the view deck.

formatted_address: 37 Leonard Wood Rd, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Baguio Botanical Garden

review.text:
Its a nice place to visit and walk around. It is a simple family spot. You can walk the park in about 45 mins. There is also a cave dug into the hillside.
For you history buffs out there. This was dug into stone and used during the Japanese occupation. There is fighting holes, storage rooms, etc.

history: This park used to be called Botanical and Zoological Garden. It has been named as Igorot Village, due to the native huts and Igorot sculptures. It was also named Imelda Park during the Marcos regimen.

formatted_address: FA 347 Bell Church Rd, La Trinidad, Benguet, Philippines
name: Bell Church

review.text: It was fine and all especially of you're interested in Chinese culture.  But there's nothing there to see. Just the temple and the grounds.  You can't even climb up the higher structures. But you can always just take pictures and pay respect.

history: The Bell Church was founded on August 4, 1960 in Benguet by a Chinese immigrants from Canton, China (now Guangzhou) led by Ng Pee. They were devotees of the Buddhist monk Ji Gong.

formatted_address: N Santo Tomas Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Maryknoll Ecological Sanctuary

review.text: It is educational. A nice place to bring your children to learn a bit of history.

history: After the 1990 earthquake that hit Baguio City, the Maryknoll Sisters decided on an alternative way to use their resources in the City of Pines and converted their elementary school as a venue for education still, but this time to focus on the fragile environment that is the planet Earth.

formatted_address: Harrison Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Harrison Road Night Market

review.text: It was fun going around the night market. There are a lot of great finds with prices that are cheap & affordable, which is also why the streets are pretty crowded.

history: Baguio City's night shopping market at Harrison Road in the city centre opens for business daily at 9pm. Having heard some horror stories both here on the Trip Advisor reviews and also at our Baguio City hotel about how crowded it could be at times I planned to make a visit here one Sunday evening when I hoped that it would not be so busy. Luckily for me I found the market hall in Harrison Road to be so quiet that some of the retailers were shutting up shop and packing up their wares before heading home to bed for an early night.

formatted_address: La Trinidad, Benguet, Philippines
name: Strawberry Farm

review.text: Well, I like the countryside and well maintained farms and La Trinidad's whole identity is invested in their agriculture culture ~ and it's not big companies but hundreds of small companies that take such care in their passion and craft. I was very pleased.

history: The strawberry farm is located in Barangay Betag of La Trinidad, Benguet and is owned and maintained by the Benguet State University (BSU). The BSU leases at least 500 to 1,000 square meters (5,400 to 10,800 sq ft) lots of the 79.49 hectares (196.4 acres) farm to local farmers for strawberry cultivation.

formatted_address: Happy Glen Loop Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Emilio F. Aguinaldo Museum

review.text: Visited EMILIO AGUINALDO MUSEUM in Baguio City to see the intriguing original flag unfurled on June 12, 1898 in Kawit, Cavite. This flag is bound for extinction after 20 years considering its decaying state. The flag was only revealed to the public by Emilio Aguinaldo in 1964 before his demise. Less than 500 visitors have only visited the museum since its construction in 1985 on Happy Glen Loop in Baguio City.

history: The Emilio F. Aguinaldo Shrine is a national shrine located in Kawit, Cavite in the Philippines, where the Philippine Declaration of Independence from Spain was declared on June 12, 1898.

formatted_address: Romulo Dr, Brgy., Lualhati, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Ketchup Food Community

review.text:
Kanto Freestyle's Lomo ribs is the best tasting rib that I tried. The rib cut is not too big but thick, very tender and the sauce is very flavorful, the side salad is unique as there's watermelon that add an exciting twist to the whole meal, with rice and not so expensive too!

Too bad they are not there anymore. There's comfort room but they need to improve the management of cleanliness. Anyways, still worth it to add in your Baguio itinerary.

history: Ketchup Food Community has become one of Baguio's landmarks when it comes to dining since it opened in 2011. Consisting of five homegrown restaurants that have created a name for themselves among foodies, Ketchup became a must-try place for those going up to Baguio.

formatted_address: Jose Abad Santos Dr, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Burnham Park

review.text: There are variety of fun activities to enjoy here - from boating, skating, biking, and more. You may also simply enjoy having a picnic with your family in the park. Such a good place to have fun in Baguio City! But always remember to be a responsible citizen or tourist. Don't ruin a good place by throwing trashes just anywhere.

history: Burnham Park is named after Daniel Burnham, an American architect who was the city planner for Baguio. He designed the park and the original plans for the city simultaneously, and construction began around 1904. Burnham Park covers the only large expanse of level ground within hilly surroundings.

formatted_address: Scout Hill Dr, Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Tree Top Adventure Baguio

review.text: Friendly staff. I think the only issue I have was that it's a bit pricey. But everything is good. Will recommend.

formatted_address: Dominican Hill, Diplomat Road, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Heritage Hill and Nature Park Garden, Baguio

review.text: Historical place very nice. Some people says its haunted mansion. I recommend this place once you visit baguio city. Free Entrance and Parking. Need more restoration of the building. Keep it up!

history: Adventure park offering zip-lining courses along with treetop climbs & cablecar rides.

formatted_address: Shanum St, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Baguio Orchidarium

review.text: Many flowers to see, I think you can buy some. It's nice. Many varieties

history: The Baguio City Orchidarium is the place for fresh plants that are sold at an affordable price. We, Travel Tripsters, love plants.

formatted_address: ME 33 Lamtang, Pico-Lamtang Road, Puguis, La Trinidad, 2601 Benguet, Philippines
name: Mount Costa

review.text:
Absolutely loved this place! 

Worth every peso if you want to quietly relax whole enjoying the different theme gardens.

Book online to get 5% discount...

I can spend a whole day in the place... can't wait to get back there!

history: The six hectare (15 acre) garden is tucked among tall pine trees on a privately owned forested - terraced mountain. Mount Costa is named in honor of proponents' ancestors, Col. Voltaire & Cleotilde Acosta, 2 inspiring Baguio pioneers whose legacy we'd like to share with you.

formatted_address: Kennon Rd, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Kennon Road Viewpoint

review.text: Very good scenic place from this place you can see the almost all the entire mountains and its beautiful

history: The Kennon Road (formerly the Benguet Road and also known as the Rosario–Baguio Road) is a roadway in Benguet province in the Philippines connecting the mountain city of Baguio to the lowland town of Rosario in La Union province. The project begun in 1903 and opened for travel on January 29, 1905.

formatted_address: Historical Core, Camp John Hay, Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Bell Amphitheater

review.text: Visit this when you are in Camp John hay... If you like romance with a touch of rusticity, this could be a place for you...

history: The Bell Amphitheater was built in 1913 and was named after its designer, General J. Franklin Bell. From then on, it became a favorite venue for concerts, weddings and other public events.

formatted_address: Gibraltar Rd, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Good Shepherd Convent

review.text: Best blueberry and strawberry jam! Too crowded on weekends or long holidays! Parking is insufficient

history: As early as 1921 the Good Shepherd Sisters at St. Bridget's Academy in Batangas, after a hard year's work, spent the summer months in Baguio. Not having a house of their own in Baguio, the sisters used to stay with the Belgian Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary or with the Maryknoll Missionary Sisters.

formatted_address: 6 Asin Rd, Tuba, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: BenCab Museum

review.text: A must visit if you like paintings, sculptures and arts in general . Its a 3 storey art museum with a cozy cafe. At the back of the building, there are fishes and huts where you can just sit and relax and enjoy the view of the nature. You can feel almost sleepy because of the fresh cold air.

history: The BenCab Museum is on Km. 6 Asin Road, a brief 15-minute drive from the center of Baguio City. Built on a promontory, the museum commands a breathtaking view of the adjacent garden, farm, hill and mini-forest, the surrounding mountains, and the South China sea in the distant west.

formatted_address: Ordonio Dr, Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Camp John Hay Eco-Trail

review.text:
This place is such a gem, LITERALLY. I just love how love and nature-y this place is. Thid place is such a good place to 'hike'(it's not really a hike but just walking a small distance  upward. If you're a jog-type of a person then this is definitely a place for you. This is also a place for a person who just want to be with nature once in a while. 
Note: Bring your own food if you want to have an inexpensive walk with nature but if you're a rich person who reeks with money then why not try the restaurants here!

history: Built to people for them to experience nature the way old Baguio used to be. The pleasure for me is the trek, discovering the trail and being surrounded with large pine trees and the scent of pine cones.

formatted_address: La Trinidad, Benguet, Philippines
name: Mt. Kalugong

review.text: Climbing atop the limestone rock formations of Mt. Kalugong offers a unique and beautiful view of La Trinidad Valley. I also enjoyed the peaceful and relaxing ambiance while enjoying my lunch at the picnic tables. They also serve delicious brewed coffee at the cafe. If you plan to visit, don't forget to wear some good hiking shoes.

history: High-altitude destination for short mountain hikes with scenic views, plus a coffee shop at the top.

formatted_address: P. Ledesma St, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: IMMACULATE CONCEPTION CHURCH

review.text: Nice church and sorroundings

history: In Christian theology, the Immaculate Conception is the conception of the Virgin Mary free from original sin by virtue of the merits of her son Jesus. The Catholic Church teaches that God acted upon Mary in the first moment of her conception, keeping her immaculate.

formatted_address: 2600, Steps To Our Lady Of Atonement Cathedral, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Cathedral of Our Lady of Atonement

review.text: Our Lady of Atonement Church offer hourly masses on Sundays. Spacious parking space for all types of vehicle with parking fees. Benches are also available outside for those who cannot access inside during crowded masses. Solemn Masses celebrates here and inspiring shared homily. Surely, a must place to visit when your around the city.

history: The building was completed by 1936, and consecrated that year, dedicated to Our Lady of Atonement. During World War II, the cathedral served as an evacuation center. It withstood the carpet-bombing of Baguio City in 1945.

formatted_address: Dominican Hill Rd, Baguio, 2600 Benguet, Philippines
name: Our Lady of Lourdes Grotto

review.text: It was our first time to visit the place. It has an aura of sacredness despite the area being crowded with devotees and tourists. The chapel provides a sanctuary where people can slip for a moment and say their prayers. I just hope that the visitors refrain from taking pictures right outside the entrance of the chapel because there is a tendency to  forget that silence should be observed, or better yet to take pictures without disturbing the peace and quiet of the chapel.

history: Now a religious grotto. Our Lady of Lourdes is a Roman Catholic title of the Blessed Virgin Mary venerated in honour of the Marian apparitions that reportedly occurred in 1858 in the vicinity of Lourdes in France.

formatted_address: Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Bell House

review.text: The Bell House used to be a cute American-style house with complete furniture so that you'd feel like you're in 1940's Baguio. When we went for a tour with my friends, the place was bare. A bit sad looking. I hope they dress it up again soon.

history: The Bell House, a historic structure named after Major General Franklin Bell is situated at the camp's Historical Core. Besides the house is the Bell Amphitheater which was designed by Bell himself.

formatted_address: Sheridan Dr, Camp John Hay, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: Butterfly Sanctuary
history: Butterfly Sanctuary. The Butterfly Sanctuary at Camp John Hay was designed around the Little Mermaid Garden that was built by American soldiers decades ago when this premier Baguio attraction was still a U.S. Armed Forces recreational facility in the Philippines.

formatted_address: 30 Gov. Pack Rd, Baguio, 2602 Benguet, Philippines
name: Museo Kordilyera

review.text: Amazing museum, hidden like a gem in UP Baguio! Small, intimate exhibits lets you interact and learn about the Cordilleran cultures up close. Quaint little bookshop and cafe, too.

history: Located inside the University of the Philippines Baguio, Museo Kordilyera is the first ethnographic museum in the Northern part of the Philippines. The three-story museum was formally opened to the public on January 31 of this year.

formatted_address: The Mansion, Romulo Dr, Baguio, Benguet, Philippines
name: The Mansion
history: The Mansion House is the official summer palace of the President of the Philippines. The mansion is located in the summer capital of the country, Baguio, situated around 5,000 feet asl in the Cordillera Central Range of northern Luzon.

formatted_address: PH, Leonard Wood Rd, Baguio, 2600
name: Teacher's Camp

review.text: One of the classic sites in the city that still has a lot of pine trees around. Old but functional structures that reflect the look of the old Baguio City are still around. Hope DepEd will find ways to preserve this historical place.

history: Teacher's Camp served as a training center for teachers from various parts of the Philippines. Teachers enroll in education special courses during the summer break. The center hosts classrooms, dormitories, cottages, dining areas, assembly halls and administrative offices. When teachers are not using the facility, the dormitories and cottages are rented to tourists. It also hosts events sponsored by government agencies.
